title: Could 5G replace my internet connection at home? - Quora

response.answer_text: It could, at some point. But it won’t compete with high-quality “broadband” services for a while, except (most likely) in small (dense) areas. The first benefit of 5G may be rural areas, places without broadband first. It’ll be a few years, at least, before 5G starts to be able to compete with existing wired services to a home. But that’s the idea: for the first time a wireless service can start to compete with wired. It’s doesn’t mean things will be apples to apples in comparison, but 5G has potential and there is some cool technology/innovation behind it — if it becomes fully realized. I personally believe I am unlikely to ditch wired for 5G anytime soon, but I will adopt 5G as a backup to my home connection… and surely as my mobile solution, etc. I suspect a lot of people underestimate the time to deploy or realize the benefits… it’s further off than most realize. Another note: the wireless providers don’t necessarily have the experience of providing homes Internet access. One of the issues is IPv4 exhaustion, the 5G services may have IPv4 proxies or translation, running on IPv6 only, etc… for the average user, that doesn’t mean much. For others, it means a lot. I need my own public (routable) IPv4 address… I’m not sure 5G will provide that.

No. Absolutely not. I would get a slower and more expensive Internet in that case. Longer ping time and slower top speed. I have optical fiber at 1000Mit/s and I expect to get an upgrade to 10 000Mbit/s within a few years. This without any sort of data caps or data limitations. a few TB in a weekend is not uncommon. So in all aspects as I can know of, a switchover to 5G would be to make my Internet experience to be much worse then it is today. I will, of course, use 5G when on the move, but at home or at the office optical fiber is the correct and best way for Internet connectivity. Now to the really interesting part. I have not met anyone that has switched over to optical fiber for the Internet that even consider using any other kind of Internet access. And in Sweden, today above 50% of all premises already have optical fiber Internet access.

If you are using a broadband connection, the answer is no, broadband is much stable than any cellular network.If you are using a shared WiFi, the answer still no, WiFi is specifically designed to penetrate through walls in order to provide faster and stable connectivity in close proximity. 5G can provide you faster speeds but not much in indoors even if it does, it won’t be as stable as WiFi.If you are already using a mobile hotspot/ mobile broadband, then probably it won’t make any difference unless the mobile manufacturers don’t enhance the power and speed of hotspot. In theory, 5G can offer comparable speeds to replace the broadband internet connection to the home - say, 100 Mbps. But there is a catch. To consistently deliver 100 Mbps to a home, and to deliver to a meaningful number of homes (say, 50) from one cell site, you need at least 100 MHz of aggregated bandwidth and this is only available in the spectrum with frequencies greater than 3.5 GHz (with one exception, Sprint’s 2.5 GHz band.) Most network planners believe that the 2.5 GHz and 3.5 GHz bands will be earmarked for mobile broadband services, which means they will be looking at frequencies above 3.5GHz for fixed broadband services. As we go higher up in frequency, the range falls off, and the walls of the house block the signal. To provide fixed broadband service, the cell site needs to be fairly close to the home (around ~ 1 km or less), be fed with fiber to the cell site, and have a rooftop antenna to recieve the signal at the home. All this adds to the cost, and the current assumption is that 5G fixed wireless access will be a niche solution that addresses situations where fiber and coaxial cable are not available.

There’s a lot of hype and misunderstanding about 5G. 5G comes in two basic flavors. The 5G being offered in most areas of the US today offers only a small advantage over 4G. The hype is about 5G over milliliter wave (MMW) bands.[1] These are very high frequencies (26 to 60 GHz). They offer about 10 times the current cellular bandwidth, but they work over only a short range and don’t penetrate walls well. Providers are experimenting with the technology now. For example, parts of Houston have MMW. Early reports are that the service is quite good. If you have access to MMW 5G with good signal strength, you will see performance more or less equivalent to what coax cable providers offer today. Whether you will ever get an MMW signal, and what it will cost, are open questions. Footnotes[1] 5G Frequency Bands & Spectrum Allocations - CableFree

It could if cost were no object, but in general home WiFi is so much more cost effective, particularly when supporting multiple devices (our house WiFi currently shows 26 devices) that 5G couldn’t compete. It turns out that even 4G LTE can provide a decent Internet connection if the local cable company is a total AH about bringing service to your house. Just this afternoon I found out that Comcast wanted to charge $3,500 to add a single house to the cable in this neighborhood. The owners, understandably, told Comcast where they could go, and opted for a much more generous data plan and hot spot.

In a simple answer NO. Any type of radio transmission will have a limit on frequencies and the amount of traffic the system can handle at one moment. Optic fibre is only limited by the speed and capacity at the terminal ends. If you could produce terminal infrastructure that has a speed of one thousand tera bits, the optic fibre would have no problem with that. However not in a snowflake chance in hell could 5G be able to do that. 5G is ok , like taking a push bike to a store, but optic fibre is like taking the F35 to the same store. Just dont believe all the hype and rubbish you hear about 5G at the moment.

probably not, wired services will always be able to provide more bandwidth than wireless. The only time where wireless is preferable will be the rural areas where laying cables is too expensive. Cost of implementing a solution to a problem become more expensive as you get closer to the theoretical maximum of the media. Current technology is a long way off the theoretical maximum of wired media but we are a bit closer to the maximum of wireless.

Verizon is already offering home Internet with 5G. Each carrier has different plans for 5G, but for sure some of them will try to win the home Internet business with it. Networks of the future will most likely be a combination of hardware types, wired and wireless…

Yes. Some years ago I used 3G in place of my landline ISP connection when the latter suffered a breakdown for several days. You will have to work out whether 5G is cost effective. I would not jump on to 5G too soon. I understand that the specifications are not yet fully ratified and published.

In flat areas with few or no trees, sure. But this assumes that the mobile providers will remove or relax their data caps enough to allow streaming video. I doubt they’ll do that. They make more money on data overages than they would on stealing cable and DSL internet customers, is my guess.

Not everyone because of lack of coverage in some rural and remote area Next comes the issue of data limits or caps on some cell plans. Then coverage in buildings or structures also is still an issue until such times as coverage technical issues are resolved. So for now the answer is no 5 G wont replace ALL wifi but soon real soon yes.
It's going to depend. 4G already replaces a lot of home Internet in the UK, because the provision of broadband via fibre or even ADSL is so terrible. So an even faster radio link? Great.

Only locally, where you have bad fixed line infrastructure (no fibre or TV coax cable; just copper pairs, with long distance to the central office). Otherwise cable supplied internet will still be faster and cheaper.
